1. Introduction
Fine particulate matter (PM) with aerodynamic diameter less
than 25 ym (PMp.) is an important air pollutant due to its ef-
fect on human health, contribution to visibility reduction and
impact on climate (Fuzzi et al, 2015). Outdoor air pollution,
including PM,., leads to approximately 3.3 million premature
deaths per year worldwide while the excess mortality rate in
Europe has been estimated to be approximately 790,000 per
year (Lelieveld et al., 2015, 
- Action 4: read_chunk

Inthe atmosphere, aerosols have a wide variety of sources,
which influences their concentration, size distribution and
chemical composition. Aerosols can be classified, accord-
ing to their sources and their formation processes, as nat-
ural or anthropogenic and as primary or secondary (Fuzzi
cet al, 2015). Natural aerosol sources include windblown soil
from arid regions, volcanic emissions, sea spray, biogenic sec-
‘ondary aerosol formation, and biomass burning from wild
fires. The major sources of anthropogenic aerosols include
fossil fuel combustion, industrial processes, waste incinera-
tion, etc. smaeilirad et al, 2020) Primary aerosols are directly
emitted into the atmosphere from natural and anthropogenic
sources, while secondary aerosols are formed through chem-
ical reactions in the atmosphere.
Although air quality has improved in many developed
countries, the Mediterranean Basin still suffers from seri-
cous air pollution. Positioned at the intersection of circulating
air masses from three continents (Europe, Asia and Africa)
the Eastern Mediterranean countries are characterized by el-
evated PM concentrations due to both locally emitted and
long-range transport, the absence of precipitation from spring
to late autumn and favorable meteorological conditions for
the formation of photochemical smog (Mantas et al., 2014;
Remoundaki et al, 2013; Pikridas et al, 2018). Lebanon is lo-
cated along the eastern coast of the Mediterranean Sea and
represents one Middle Eastern country where PM levels have
been found to regularly surpass the World Health Organiza
tion (WHO) standards (LNSAQM, 2017); the average concen-
trations of PM; were six to ten times higher than the maxi-
mum mean yearly guidelines set by WHO (5 p/m?) (Abdallah
cet al,,2018; Borgie etal, 2016; WHO, 2021). Long-range trans-
port of dust from deserts in the fall and spring seasons (Sal-
iba et al, 2007) and potential sulfate from Eastern and Cen-
tral Europe (Aff et al., 2008) contribute to elevated PM con-
centrations. Other significant local sources of pollution are
road transport, industrial emissions, and electricity produc
tion (Waked et al, 2012; Waked and Afif, 2012).
